text: “Have you ever heard the lyrics to that song?” she asked. “It’s like they were written for us.” https://t.co/wI852UIO5u

name: nytimes
text: What happens to indoor plants when New Yorkers flee during a pandemic? Some get left at the curb, while some get cared for by professionals or their owners' friends. https://t.co/k4ZYF0EAs2

name: nytimes
text: Before New York became the city that never sleeps, Manhattan was a lush forested island filled with wildlife. Our architecture critic @kimmelman and the conservation ecologist Eric W. Sanderson take us on a tour of the city as it once was. https://t.co/OpsUygTZMd

name: nytimes
text: The robe is just one of many cozy styles catching on in isolation; sweatsuits, pajamas and slippers have also seen an uptick in sales https://t.co/j9TWSbz6IM

text: Amy Schumer talks about her new cooking show, her son's name, insisting Jerry Seinfeld watch "Normal People" and writing jokes in isolation https://t.co/iL7xH77jVt

text: From brownstones to shipyards, take a virtual stroll of Brooklyn with a historian https://t.co/ZR1bemPIVe

name: nytimes
text: A magnitude-5.8 earthquake struck New Zealand on Monday, while Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern was doing a live television interview. She seemed unruffled, fitting a pattern of calm in crisis that she has displayed before. https://t.co/35wLJBEHZj

name: nytimes
text:
RT @amyyqin: The Chinese government is calling for a revolution - a 'dining table revolution.' 

In its battle to suppress the coronavirus, China has zeroed in on family-style dining and the most humble, yet beloved, of utensils: the chopstick https://t.co/crUaDG1IxW

name: nytimes
text: An oil tanker called “Fortune” has sailed into Venezuela from Iran, the first of 5 ships expected to arrive in a nation so starved of gasoline that the docking of a single tanker was hailed by government officials as a victory https://t.co/q32ZXhZ4MZ

name: nytimes
text: RT @adamgoldmanNYT: The conditions inside the 247-bed, state-run home, where Mr. Miller had lived for five years, were so chaotic that his children cannot recount them without breaking down. ⁦@EllenBarryNYT⁩  https://t.co/vvVq43bpQA

name: nytimes
text: Faced with the spread of the coronavirus, the Chinese government is promoting using serving utensils. But resistance is strong. Sharing food with personal chopsticks is one way Chinese people, like many elsewhere in the world, express affection. https://t.co/Xt7S2zimR6

text: A mass firing on Zoom is the latest sign of unrest at Weight Watchers https://t.co/IWuoOWEE56

text: The casino tycoon Stanley Ho led the transformation of the tiny territory of Macau off the coast of China into the world’s most lucrative gambling destination. He is dead at 98. https://t.co/bCg8lDdUzU

name: nytimes
text: The virus has ravaged nursing homes across Europe and the United States. But the death toll in British homes is becoming a defining scandal of the pandemic for Prime Minister Boris Johnson. https://t.co/F6yv9PWILq

text: The British luxury carmaker Aston Martin is re-creating the James Bond's car from the 1964 movie “Goldfinger,” with all the (responsible) spy gear it could stuff into it https://t.co/HY2lztBHwJ

text: One judge expects as many as 150,000 people to file for bankruptcy, up from a few thousand last year. Lawyers representing Spaniards who lost loved ones to the virus have already filed a lawsuit against the government. https://t.co/SZVhtnjnxE

name: nytimes
text: Hong Kong's leader dismissed concerns that Beijing’s new legislation would allow police officers to arbitrarily arrest protesters. “We are a very free society, so for the time being, people have this freedom to say whatever they want to say,” she said. https://t.co/z5uG1YTaPg

name: nytimes
text: Frederico Varandas is the president of Sporting Clube de Portugal, one of the country’s biggest soccer teams. He is also a former military doctor who returned to duty to assist in the nation’s battle against the coronavirus. https://t.co/2vzlEt06vV

name: nytimes
text: Some state and local health departments have refused to disclose the number of virus cases in U.S. meatpacking plants, citing privacy concerns. That secrecy may have hastened the spread of the disease. https://t.co/SYHvE6lSvr

name: nytimes
text: Though the number of new deaths has trended downward, the virus continues to circulate widely within the U.S. As states move to partly reopen their economies, thousands of new cases are still being identified each day. https://t.co/Ts11Ir4FG2

name: nytimes
text: The Irish government has rejected claims that the country’s leader breached Ireland’s coronavirus lockdown rules when he was pictured socializing with his partner and 2 friends in Dublin’s Phoenix Park on Sunday https://t.co/WTfWUx3zB9

text: The Air Force has removed its minimum height requirement for prospective pilots in a move that it said would encourage a more diverse pool of applicants, particularly women https://t.co/rFhxRNaXtc

text: Two brothers died of the coronavirus within hours of each other in New Jersey. Their family is fighting to have them buried in their home country, but the pandemic has made this almost impossible. Listen to today's episode of "The Daily." https://t.co/DT7XAltvW8

name: nytimes
text: For decades, the U.S. has been the world master at logistics, the fine art of making Thing A and moving it to Point B. But the coronavirus has upended the American logistics machine right when it's most needed. https://t.co/2R6zctx9Rj

name: nytimes
text:
When Las Vegas reopens, it will be a very different place.

Many of the flashiest hotels and casinos will remain closed. The famed all-you-can-eat buffets will be gone. So will the nightclubs. It is unknown when must-see live shows will return. https://t.co/taH9ISFXbX

name: nytimes
text:
The U.S. Supreme Court refused a Trump administration request to block a ruling requiring prison officials to move more than 800 older or medically vulnerable prisoners from a facility in Ohio that has seen 9 deaths from Covid-19
https://t.co/OI6W809jRE
